title-group.subtitle: A Comparison of the Category Productions of LSES and MSES Elementary School Children

article-meta.aff: 3University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Rihana S. Williams, Emmanuel College, 181 Spring St., P.O. Box 49, Franklin Springs, GA 30639 Email: rwilliams@ec.edu

abstract.p: The current study compares the productivity (number of responses) and the typical responses to taxonomic and slot-filler prompts in 39 African American children from low-income backgrounds and a diverse group of 21 children from middle-income backgrounds. The authors tested the hypothesis that socioeconomic status would exert a global influence on productivity and typicality responses such that children from middle-income environments would generate higher productivity rates and more sophisticated typical responses. They found support for this hypothesis only in categories that appear to be related to exposure to formal contexts. Several categories that reflect basic life experiences displayed similar rates of productivity and typical responses across socioeconomic groups. Findings from this study have implications for the assessment of semantic knowledge in elementary-school-age children from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds.

body.p: Reciprocal relations between children’s semantic knowledge and reading comprehension during the elementary school years have been well documented. Greater semantic knowledge leads to better reading comprehension and vice versa (Beck & McKeown, 1983; Scarborough, 2005). Given these relations, studying the semantic development of young children living in poverty is important because they are less frequently exposed to advanced language and often enter school knowing drastically fewer words than children raised in middle- and upper-class homes (Hart & Risley, 1995; White, Graves, & Slater, 1990). These developmental trajectories are set early and are difficult to change, placing many children from low-income environments at risk for later reading disabilities (Hart & Risley, 1995). Thus, we need to not only understand which kinds of semantic knowledge children bring to the task of learning how to read but also consider what factors contribute to variation in children’s semantic knowledge.

Researchers have used category production tasks, also known as semantic fluency tasks, to expressively measure children’s conceptual and semantic organization. On these tasks, children are presented orally with a category (e.g., fruits) and asked to provide as many related words as they can think of (e.g., apple, orange, healthy, dessert, etc.). Exemplars that are produced in response to a category prompt are thought to index children’s event schemas. These event schemas develop according to children’s interaction with their environment, including their dialogue with adults.

Some researchers contend that children as young as 3 years have a preference toward slot-filler or schematic categories. Slot-filler representations maintain the temporal order and functional and spatial relations among parts of everyday life experiences (Lucariello, Kyratzis, & Nelson, 1992; Riva, Nichelli, & Devoti, 2000). For example, to younger children, boot is a slot filler to the category clothing that is worn outside. These items are grouped together in memory because they are grouped together in everyday life. As children get older, their preference for slot-filler categories shifts toward taxonomic or hierarchical categories (Lucariello et al., Mpofu & Vijver, 2000; Nelson, 1974; Nelson & Nelson, 1990). Representations that are organized taxonomically are stored based on perceptual commonalities among the objects being represented rather than temporal or spatial characteristics. In other words, taxonomic categories are based exclusively on objects or terms that share meaning. For instance, when presented with the category shoe, older children may say slipper or tennis shoe. These items may be grouped together in memory because they represent objects that are inanimate and can share the same general shape.

Although the developmental preference toward slot-filler categories has been replicated, it does not appear to be universal in Western cultures. Researchers have observed children from different experiential backgrounds to demonstrate this preference at relatively similar ages. For instance, in a study with children from low socioeconomic (LSES) backgrounds, Nelson and Nelson (1990) found that kindergarteners provided the same amount of exemplars when prompted with slot-filler and taxonomic category labels, whereas second graders provided more exemplars to taxonomic than to slot-filler category labels. This pattern has been replicated for bilingual Spanish-speaking children in the United States (Pena, Bedore, & Zlatic-Giunta, 2002). In contrast, several researchers have not found any differences in the ability to categorize on the basis of slot-filler and taxonomic relations in 6- to 8-year-old children when the task was implicit (Blewitt & Toppino, 1991; Hashimoto, McGregor, & Graham, 2007).

Moreover, researchers have also found that the quantity of exemplars produced and the organization of exemplars within taxonomic and slot-filler prompts can vary by external factors, such as SES. Bjorklund and Weiss (1985) demonstrated that upper SES kindergarten and first graders produced more taxonomic clusters for items on a free recall list than did lower SES children. Crowe and Prescott (2003) found evidence that children in the United Kingdom from the lower-middle and upper-middle classes organize the animal category according to the environments in which they are encountered. These environments include the home, zoo, and farm. This experiential ordering is consistent across children ages of 5 through 10 years. Older children show more sophistication in their categories, such that they are able to produce more nonmammals and invertebrates then mammals compared to younger children.

Findings from studies employing category production tasks are somewhat different in non-Western cultures. For instance, the preference toward slot-filler categories does not appear to extend to groups who differ by their socioeconomic status. Mpofu (2002) found that 7- to 11-year-old children who varied by levels of SES did not show differences in their slot-filler category performance. However, as in Western cultures, studies involving children from non-Western cultures have also observed SES differences in the quantity of category productions. For instance, Mpofu also found that children from higher SES backgrounds provided significantly more taxonomic category responses than children from LSES backgrounds. This pattern has also been replicated among Korean children (Yu & Nelson, 1993).

The ordering of members within categories has also received considerable attention. It is hypothesized that the order of response to a category prompt reflects one’s underlying conceptual structure. This assumption follows from studies that have demonstrated that items named together are related in memory (Neely, 1991). Order of responses reflects the relative proximity of items in memory, with first or typical responses being most salient in memory. Because categories are assumed to be organized around the most typical members, more typical members are thought to be named first in category production tasks. In contrast, items named toward the end of a list are atypical and do not share the same features or characteristics as earlier named items. Moreover, more typical members are generally learned before atypical members of groups. Researchers have not observed a consistent pattern of developmental change in typical responses. Some studies have reported a difference in typical responses between ages 6 and 8 years (Nelson, 1974), whereas others have shown no difference (Crowe & Prescott, 2003; Lucariello et al., 1992).

Certain vocabulary items are more or less typical for children, depending on their culture, Pena et al. (2002) demonstrated that the category itself influences whether taxonomic or slot-filler organization is preferred and that the nature of the preference is largely experiential. Certain categories like animals elicited more exemplars compared to food and clothing in English–Spanish bilingual 4- to 7-year-old children. When the category referred to animals, bilingual children provided more exemplars in response to a taxonomic category prompt than in response to a slot-filler category prompt. The researchers also noted that children produced fewer items in the slot-filler category zoo animals than the taxonomic category animals, when children were not exposed to a particular event like going to the zoo. This finding suggests two important characteristics of semantic memory organization: (a) event exposure realized in personal experiences shapes stored events in memory and (b) the amount of words known or that exists in a child’s vocabulary influence whether these words are organized taxonomically or not.

In sum, taxonomic categories aid children in organizing and accessing multiple scripts. These scripts allow children to organize the vocabulary they gain across languages and cultures accurately and efficiently. Moreover, cultural, linguistic, and socioeconomic factors appear to influence the type, amount, and order of category responses produced by children.

sec.title: Semantic Development of African American Children From Low-Income Backgrounds
sec.p: Relatively little is known about the semantic and conceptual development of African American children. Despite the heterogeneous nature of the U.S. African American population, African American children tend to experience poorer academic achievement outcomes than White children. These so-called achievement gaps exist on school entry, persist through high school, and are complicated by associated factors such as language, SES, and school context (Entwisle, Alexander, & Olson, 1997; Fryer & Levitt, 2004; Jencks & Phillips, 1998).

In the United States, poor African American children tend to enter elementary school with smaller vocabularies than poor White children and children from higher SES backgrounds (Champion, Hyter, McCabe, & Bland- Stewart, 2003; Duncan & Magnuson, 2005; Farkas & Bergon, 2004; Hart & Risley, 1995). White et al. (1990) reported differences in reading vocabulary favoring children from upper-income homes. First grade children from middle- and upper-income environments often enter school knowing approximately twice as many words as their lower-income peers. Although SES differences are implicated in these findings, variation in children’s semantic knowledge cannot be explained fully by SES. In addition to language or linguistic differences (Craig & Washington, 2006), some researchers have suggested that standardized measures of vocabulary knowledge may not capture all that African American children know about words (Champion et al., 2003; Pence, Bojczyk, & Williams, 2007; Qi, Kaiser, Milan, & Hancock, 2006). Discussing this issue, Pena (2001) suggested that African American children’s apparent low vocabulary skills may result from a disconnect among performance on one-word receptive picture vocabulary tests, their conceptual knowledge, the links they have formed between these concepts, and the knowledge they have on the multiple meanings that words can convey.

It seems plausible that a category production paradigm would be useful in investigations of African American children’s semantic development because the tasks appear to be sensitive to race, schooling, SES, and language differences among young children. There is evidence that even when there are vocabulary size differences (i.e., Hashimoto et al., 2007) there children demonstrate the ability to categorize using both slot-filler and taxonomic relations. Moreover, performance on a category production task has the potential to replicate previous findings related to vocabulary size differences between children from LSES and middle socioeconomic (MSES) backgrounds but also extend the literature by demonstrating similarities or universal patterns in semantic organization. LSES performance on the category production task also allows one to characterize their semantic knowledge in terms of size (the number of entries per category) and typicality (similarity of prototypes), which is not possible on standardized receptive vocabulary protocols.

sec.title: Purpose of the Study
sec.p: The current study extended previous literature on cultural and linguistic differences in semantic category organization (Pena et al., 2002). Specifically, we investigated whether African American children from LSES and children from MSES backgrounds differed in their semantic category productivity and organizational strategies and, if so, whether differences were related to the category prompts used. We hypothesized that to the extent that SES globally influences category productivity and typicality we would observe higher productivity (number of responses given to a category prompt) and more typical exemplars in MSES children. It was also hypothesized that experiential differences would be maximized on taxonomic categories because this type of category production requires a greater sophistication of semantic knowledge. To address this hypothesis, we examined, both between and within SES groups, the number of responses children provided to slot-filler and taxonomic categories as well as the order of responses.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: All participants volunteered as part of a larger ongoing study related to language and literacy in a large urban city in the U.S. Southeast. Children were included if they were administered the oral vocabulary test that was relevant to the current study. This excluded 10 participants from the larger study. Two groups of children enrolled in elementary school were recruited to participate in this study. Parental consent and child (both verbal and written) assent were gathered for each participant according to the guidelines set forth by the institutional review board of the research institution and the governing body of the parochial school. Group SES was determined by average household income level of the neighborhoods or parishes associated with the schools represented by the participants in this study. This information was obtained from publicly available records for each school. Lunch status is a common indicator of SES because only families with low household incomes are qualified to participate in the programs.

A total of 39 African American children (67% female) constituted the LSES group. These students attended one of nine public elementary schools in a large metropolitan area in the Southeast. All of the schools were in high-poverty neighborhoods. The average median household income level was $24,147 (SD = $4,668). The mean age of the LSES group was 6 years 2 months (range = 5, 8 to 6, 8). Assessment occurred during the late spring of the academic year.

The MSES group consisted of a diverse group of 21 children (67% female) from middle-income backgrounds. Children in the MSES group attended one private parochial school in the same large metropolitan area in the Southeast and were included in this study as a comparison group. The MSES group was racially diverse and included African American (55%) and White (35%), Asian American (10%) children. The mean age of the MSES group was 7 years 0 months (range = 5, 4 to 8, 4). The average income level was $60,213. The average household size was fewer than three persons. Assessment occurred during the beginning of the fall of the academic year.

sec.title: Category production task
sec.p: An experimental measure, KidCategories, was designed for this study. This category production task was based on the protocols used in previous research studies (Nelson & Nelson, 1990; Pena et al., 2002). Form A of KidCategories was the slot-filler condition, which included 39 prompts; Form B, the taxonomic condition, included 37 prompts. The order of prompts was randomized within each form to offset any effects that fatigue might have on the participant’s responses. All items from Nelson and Nelson’s 1990 study were retained. Taxonomic prompts from this study included animals, clothing, and food, whereas slot-filler prompts included animals found on a farm and zoo, clothing worn inside and outside, and food eaten for breakfast and lunch.

sec.title: Oral receptive vocabulary task
sec.p: The Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test, Fourth Edition (PPVT-4; Dunn & Dunn, 2007) was included in this study both as a standardized measure of receptive vocabulary and as an index of breadth of vocabulary knowledge. Prompts from the PPVT-4 are administered in ascending difficulty across sets of 12 items each. Within an individual set, the prompts are arranged so that the first three prompts are the easiest, the last three are the second easiest, and the middle six are the most difficult. The PPVT-4 was administered and scored in standardized format according to test manual guidelines.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Participants were tested by a trained team of three professors, three graduate students from the educational psychology program, and three psychology undergraduate students from the research institution. All team members had previous experience administering standardized language and literacy assessments. All research team members received the same training, which was conducted by the first and third authors. Each member of the research team was required to successfully test out of a training session by administering the assessments correctly to another team member. The tasks were all given in a quiet area of the schools at designated times, which spanned the entire school day. Whenever possible, the entire assessment battery was given in a single session. However, some of the youngest children in the study required an additional session to complete the task.

sec.title: Kid categories
sec.p:
Participants were randomly assigned to receive either Form A or Form B. The researcher introduced the task by saying,
Today I want to play a word game with you. You may not have played this game before so let me explain it to you. I am going to say the name of some THINGS. After I say a name, you tell me all of the things that you can think of that belong with that name. When you tell me the things that you think of I will be writing them down. When you finish, I will give you the name of something else. I may say TOOLS and you may think of hammers, pliers, screwdrivers, and lots of other things.

Then, the child was given two practice trials. The first practice trial was “toys,” and after the child responded, the researcher followed by saying, “Those are very good. You could probably have thought of ‘blocks, dolls, transformers, cars, trucks, balls, trains’” and other toys that the child did not mention.

The researchers began the trials by saying, “Ok. Now remember each time I tell you a word, you say all the things that you can think of that belong with the word I say. Try to name as many things as you can.” They followed by saying, “This is not a race, so speak clearly so that I can write down the words that you say. Let’s get started. Are you ready?” The researchers then read each of the names from a worksheet and recorded each response given by the participant verbatim. If the participant paused while responding, the researcher prompted the child by saying any of the following: “Can you think of any other ________?” “And?” “And what else?” “ Is there more?” “Yes,” “Uh-huh,” and “Mm-hmm.” Participants were prompted until they said “That’s it or I don’t know anymore.” Participants’ responses were recorded verbatim on an answer sheet.

sec.title: Scoring kid categories
sec.p: To obtain the score for a particular category, we counted the total number of generated words that were representative of each category. For slot-filler prompts the scores are an average of multiple categories (i.e., animals in the park or woods, animals in the zoo, etc.). All responses that were nonwords, repetitions, or unrelated by feature or function were not counted as representative and excluded from analysis.

sec.title: Receptive Vocabulary Performance
sec.p: Replicating prior findings in the literature, the MSES group had larger vocabularies than the LSES group. LSES participants in the current study obtained a mean standard score of 94.95 (SD = 11.36) on the PPVT-4, whereas the MSES participants obtained a mean standard score of 110.87 (SD = 10.97). The range of standard scores for LSES participants was 75–121. The range of standard scores for MSES was 93–131. The results of a one-way ANOVA using group as an independent variable revealed a significant difference between groups, F(1, 53) = 22.73, p < .0001, η2 = .30.

sec.title: Slot filler versus taxonomic
sec.p: Composite scores were made for the major subcategorizations of slot-filler categories so that comparisons could be made between similar subcategorizations of taxonomic categories. We eliminated one outlier for the category food, a participant’s score of 45. The mean numbers of responses in each slot-filler and taxonomic category are displayed by group in Table 1. Since our participants varied in age, age was entered as a covariate. Age did not have a significant effect and was not considered in any of the remaining analyses. Overall, children produced more exemplars to taxonomic (6.75 items) prompts than to slot-filler (4.73 items) prompts. A 2 (prompt: taxonomic vs. slot filler) × 3 (category: animals vs. food vs. clothing) analysis of variance revealed significant main effects of prompt, F(1, 267) = 16.979, p < .001, η2 = .06, and category, F(2, 267) = 7.19, p < .001, η2 = .05. Post hoc comparisons indicated that within the taxonomic prompts, the animal (8.70) and food categories (9.00) generated more responses than the clothing (5.57) category. There was no interaction.

caption.p: Group Taxonomic and Slot-Filler Production by Category Type and Socioeconomic Status (SES)

sec.title: Slot-filler categorization by SES
sec.p: Table 2 displays means and standard deviations for each slot-filler category. The means were numerically similar across LSES and MSES participants produced to slot-filler prompts. Results of a multivariate analysis of variance indicated that there were no significant differences between the means for animals in the zoo, animals on the farm, animals in the water, foods for breakfast, foods for snack, foods for dinner, and clothing worn outside. The only slot-filler prompt that yielded different amounts of responses between LSES and MSES participants was animals in the park/woods F(1, 23) = 6.61, p = .02, η2 = .22.

caption.p: Slot-Filler Typicality Comparisons by Socioeconomic Status (SES) Group

fn.p: Significant mean differences between low SES and middle SES groups.

sec.p: Both groups produced a similar number of responses across all slot-filler categories. LSES participants produced a mean of 4.80 responses for food, 4.42 responses for animals, and 3.8 responses for clothing slot-filler categories. MSES participants produced a mean of 4.64 responses for food, 5.36 responses for animals, and 4.70 responses for clothing slot-filler categories. The results of a paired samples t test revealed that the mean number of response produced in food slot filler category and animal slot filler category were not statistically different from one another for LSES participants, t(14) = 1.36, p = .20, d = 0.29, or for MSES participants, t(10) = −1.28, p = .23, d = −0.33. The results of a paired samples t test also revealed that the mean numbers of responses produced in food slot filler category and clothing slot filler category were not statistically different from one another for LSES participants, t(14) = 1.61, p = .13, d = 0.47, or for MSES participants, t(9) < 1. The final set of a paired samples t test comparisons revealed that the mean numbers of responses produced in animal slot filler category and clothing slot filler category were not statistically different from one another for LSES participants, t(14) < 1, or for MSES participants, t(9) = −1.41, p = .19, d = 0.41.

sec.title: Taxonomic categorization by SES
sec.p: To see if there were any taxonomic categories that were sensitive to differences in SES, 18 taxonomic categories were examined. These categories included the 3 categories that directly corresponded to slot-filler categories (animals, food, and clothing) and 15 additional categories (fruits, vegetables, meats, drinks, mammals, reptiles, amphibians, insects, furniture, colors, instruments, utensils, soups, sauces, and jobs). Tables 1 and 3 show the means and standard deviations for each category. MSES participants produced more responses for 11 categories than LSES participants. Results of multivariate analysis of variance demonstrated significant differences for these categories, including animals, fruit, vegetables, mammals, reptiles, amphibians, soups, sauces, instruments, utensils, and jobs, F(1, 12) = 4.51, p = .05, η2 = .27.

caption.p: Taxonomic Categories Typicality by Socioeconomic Status (SES) Group

fn.p: Significant differences between low SES and middle SES groups.

sec.p: Seven categories were universal for LSES and MSES participants. Results of a multivariate analysis of variance demonstrated that there were not significant differences for these categories, including clothing, food, insects, drinks, colors, furniture, and meats, F < 1.

Several post hoc comparisons were conducted to further ascertain differences or similarities between SES groups in their responses to taxonomic categories. The results of paired samples t tests revealed that there was no significant difference between the mean number of productions in the food and animal categories for MSES participants, t(9) = −0.253, p = .806, d = −0.36. There was also no significant difference between the mean number of productions in the food and clothing categories, t(9) = 1.621, p = .140, d = −0.79. There was, however a significant difference between the mean number of productions in the animals and clothing categories, t(9) = 2.979, p < .01, d = −1.17. The results of a paired samples t test revealed that LSES participants produced the highest number of responses in the food and animals categories. The mean number productions in the food category were not statistically different from the mean number of productions in the animals category, t(16) = −1.19, p = .25, d = 0.80. In contrast, participants produced fewer mean number of responses for the clothing category compared to food, t(16) = 3.89, p < .01, d = 1.09, and animals, t(20) = 3.99, p < .01, d = −0.80.

sec.title: Slot-filler category typicality
sec.p: The most typical responses (first produced) and rank of ordering for each slot-filler category by each SES group is displayed in Table 2. Animals had four slot-filler categories. The typical response to animals on the farm by participants in the LSES group was cow, whereas the typical response by MSES participants was pig. The typical response to animals at the zoo by participants in the LSES group was zebra, whereas the typical response by MSES participants was monkey. Table 2 shows that even though the first response differs for animals on the farm and animals at the zoo, the other top responses overlap across SES groups. The typical response to animals in water by participants in both the LSES and MSES groups was fish. Even though the productivity for animals in the parks/woods differed by SES groups, both LSES and MSES participants generated dog as a first response.

There were three slot-filler categories for food. LSES and MSES participant provided cereal as a typical response to foods for breakfast. The typical response to foods for snack by participants in the LSES group was candy, whereas the typical response by MSES participants was crackers. The typical response to foods for dinner by participants in the LSES group was chicken, whereas the typical response by MSES participants was rice.

There was only one slot-filler category used for clothing. The most common first response for LSES participants to clothing worn outside was shirt. MSES participants produced shirt and jeans as typical responses for clothing worn outside.

sec.title: Taxonomic category typicality
sec.p: The most typical responses (first produced) and other frequent first responses for each taxonomic category are displayed in Table 3. The typical responses of four universal categories (drinks, colors, furniture, and meats) did not differ between LSES and MSES participants. The typical response for drinks was soda. The typical response for colors was red. The typical response for furniture was sofa or couch. The typical response for meats was chicken.

Eight taxonomic categories (animals, fruit, vegetables, sauces, soups, utensils, mammals, and reptiles) that generated higher productivity by MSES participants elicited similar typical responses as LSES participants. The typical response to animals by participants in the LSES group was giraffe, whereas the typical response by MSES participants was dog. The typical response for fruits was apple. The typical response for vegetables was carrot. The typical response for sauces was hot sauce. The typical response for soups was chicken noodle. The typical response for utensils was fork. The typical response for mammals was humans. The typical response for reptiles was alligator.

The categories foods, clothing, and insects were similar in productivity and had overlapping rankings but not typical responses. The most common first response for LSES participants to clothing was shirt compared to skirt, which was most commonly produced by the MSES participants for clothing. The other most frequent productions by LSES participants for the clothing category were shorts and pants. Suit and jeans were the only other two first responses mentioned by MSES participants for clothing. Although LSES participant provided chicken and macaroni as typical responses to food, there was no consensus for typical responses produced by MSES participants. The other first responses by LSES participants for the food category were apple and spaghetti. There other first responses by MSES participants for food included spaghetti, pasta, apple, fruit, corn, noodle, potato, pizza, and hotdog. LSES participants provided spider whereas MSES participants provided ant for insects.

In contrast, amphibians, jobs, and instruments produced different productivity rates and different first responses. LSES participants did not provide any responses to amphibian whereas MSES participants consistently provided frog as their first response. LSES participants responded with Wal-Mart whereas MSES participants responded with police for the category jobs. LSES participants responded with drums whereas MSES participants responded with trumpet for the category instruments.

sec.title: Slot-Filler Versus Taxonomic Category Productions
sec.p: We observed a difference in the productivity of taxonomic and slot-filer categories. Children from both LSES and MSES backgrounds produced more responses to taxonomic prompts (food and animals) than to slot-filler prompts. The exemplars of the category of clothing were similar in productivity and typicality when both taxonomic and slot-filler prompts were used. The advantage in productivity for food and animals is consistent with previous categorization research with 6- to 8-year-old children (Nelson & Nelson, 1990; Pena et al., 2002; Yu & Nelson, 1993). The nonemergence of a preference toward slot-filler categories in this sample is consistent with other findings that children can be trained to use taxonomic structure (Deak & Bauer, 1995). Formal instruction for both groups may have affected their ability to become flexible with taxonomic organization.

The traditional advantageous effects of exposure to middle income environments were demonstrated in the higher productivity and different typicality responses for 10 taxonomic prompts. These prompts included fruit, vegetables, mammals, reptiles, amphibians, soups, sauces, instruments, utensils, and jobs. For these categories the productivity rates are similar to older children (Crowe & Prescott, 2003; Nash & Snowling, 2008) and children who have been exposed to formal academic training (Nelson & Nelson, 1990). The typical responses of MSES children are also consistent with typicality ratings in older children (Nelson, 1974) and adults (Heit & Barsalou, 1996; Vallee-Tourangeau, Anthony, & Austin, 1998). In contrast, the productivity rates for LSES children are similar to younger children (Nelson, 1974). The typical responses of LSES children are consistent with typicality ratings in older children (Nelson, 1974), atypical members of adult categories (Heit & Barsalou, 1996; Vallee-Tourangeau et al., 1998). These patterns taken together suggest that MSES children have expanded their event schemas to incorporate broader structures that occur in natural language than have LSES children.

The rankings of productivity rates in the three widely studied taxonomic categories diverged somewhat from the previous literature with children in Western culture. MSES children displayed a pattern where food = animals, food = clothing, and animals > clothing. LSES children displayed a pattern where food = animals > clothing. Nelson and Nelson (1990) found that the food category produced the greatest quantity of responses across kindergarten and second grade children from low- to lower-middle-class backgrounds, whereas Pena et al. (2002) observed a pattern in bilingual (64% received free or reduced-price lunch) where the greatest productivity was elicited by the animals taxonomic prompt. In addition, the productivity rates of these taxonomic and their corresponding slot-filler categories fell in between Nelson and Nelson’s study and Pena et al.’s study. However, the productivity to taxonomic prompts is similar to data from typically developing children in the United Kingdom (Crowe & Prescott, 2003; Nash & Snowling, 2008). This pattern of productivity suggests that children 6–8 in Western cultures have equally formed concepts for food and animals. The pattern that fewer responses were generated by clothing could be accounted for by lack of exposure to exemplars in both groups. Both LSES and MSES participants in this study attended schools that required them to wear uniforms.

sec.title: Universal Categories
sec.p: Children bring a variety of language experiences that they acquired from their cultural environments into their elementary school classrooms. However, our data reflect commonalities among experiential contexts for LSES and MSES children’s development during primary grades. There was no difference in productivity for the following taxonomic categories: clothing, food, furniture, colors, insects, meats, drinks, and all slot-filler categories except animals in the park/woods. In addition, when given the prompts meats, drinks, and colors, LSES participants also produced identical first responses.

In response to slot-filler prompts, when LSES participants produced similar mean responses as the MSES children, they produced the different first responses. Heit and Barsalou (1996) propose the instantiation principle for category learning. This principle states that category productions are influenced by an individual’s personalized experiences and events. The pattern of different typical exemplars of slot-filler categories is consistent with this viewpoint.

New findings regarding the similarity between well-formed and poorly formed categories emerged from this study. Both LSES and MSES participants had the greatest rates of productivity to colors, food, and animals. Both groups also produced the fewest exemplars for two subordinate animal categories, amphibians and reptiles. Clearly, the well-formed and poorly formed categories reflect similarities in the level of instruction that is provided to children between the ages of 6 and 8 years.

Several other factors may account for the data patterns and the response variability observed in this study. As noted earlier, participants in this study were exposed not only to very different SES backgrounds but also different school contexts. The differences in school contexts probably arose because of SES differences. LSES participants attended public schools, whereas MSES participants attended a private school that required tuition. LSES and MSES participants were thus exposed to teachers with different levels of training, different curricula, and different instructional resources.

Inherent in the differences in school context were also perhaps differences in cultural backgrounds. Our MSES participants varied in their racial/ethnic backgrounds compared to LSES participants. In addition, our LSES participants were on average 1 year younger than our MSES participants. Previous research has focused mainly on the differences between 6- and 8-year-old children. For this age range there is no consensus that older means different or more sophisticated. The effects of cognitive maturation between ages 6 and 7 should be explored as a factor in future studies.

These data also further substantiate that categorical knowledge is acquired through social-linguistic sharing. African American LSES children were of particular interest because they provide an insight into the way in which items are categorized by individuals from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds. Data from this study showed that African American children from LSES backgrounds had extensive semantic representations for many categories, some of which were as extensive as their MSES peers. Despite the cultural and linguistic differences, common events and experiences influence the development of both African American LSES children and MSES children. These events and experiences appear to be the ones that occur outside of formal settings.

The differences observed between SES groups underscore the ongoing need to conduct vocabulary assessments so that instruction can be tailored to the learner’s needs. Standardized protocols include exemplars of categories that are more likely to be encountered in formal settings. The type of category production task used in this study is easily amenable by practitioners to test children’s knowledge of words experienced in diverse settings. Practitioners can administer the assessment in a brief manner by restricting the time per prompt to 1 minute each and selecting categories that are relevant to the focus of instruction. Future studies can improve on this investigation by administering repeated measurements close in time to gather reliability data for the category prompt assessment.

There is emerging evidence that this type of assessment of semantic knowledge has utility in children with disabilities (e.g., Down syndrome) and is correlated with performance on receptive vocabulary protocols that are commonly administered as part of traditional screening and progress monitoring batteries (Nash & Snowling, 2008). The usage of a category fluency test can be made flexible such that it includes various modes of communication such as pointing, gestures, signs, and the selection of symbols. This flexibility may be a more comprehensive way to assess all referents to objects and entities experienced throughout daily experiences. Relations among performance on category production tasks and performance on standardized measures of expressive and receptive vocabulary and standardized measures of reading comprehension should be explored.
